articles.title: Scientists issue dire warning as iconic American city sinks into the sea: 'Human intervention has made it worse'
articles.author: Timothy McGill
articles.summary: New Orleans is sinking at the rate of one to two inches per year, according to NASA and researchers at Tulane University. Rising sea levels on our overheating planet are exacerbating the problem. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has projected sea levels to rise 1.4 to 2.8 feet by the end of this century.

articles.title: Opinion: The climate conundrum facing political leaders: The public wants to have it both ways
articles.author: David Tindall
articles.summary: According to the 2025 Climate Performance Index, Canada ranks 62nd of 67 countries. Canada is the lowest-ranked of the G7 and one of the lowest of G20. Despite worsening climate change and lacklustre federal climate action, the issue has been on the back burner in current election debates. The governing Liberals have scrapped the consumer carbon tax and there is renewed talk about building new oil and gas pipelines.

articles.title: Can the legal system catch up with climate science?
articles.author: John Timmer
articles.summary: A few decades ago, it wasn't realistic to attribute individual events to the general warming trend driven by human-caused climate change. Now, there are peer-reviewed methods of rapidly detecting humanity's fingerprints in the wake of weather disasters. Dartmouth's Christopher Callahan and Justin Mankin argue that we've reached a similar level of sophistication regarding the economic damages caused by individual climate events.

articles.title: Stossel: Living Hell?
articles.author: JOHN STOSSEL
articles.summary: 'Climate change will make earth a living hell!' claims popular astrophysicist Neil DeGrasse Tyson. I don't believe him, because he doesn't believe in climate change. He's a fool.       .   -

articles.title: Crews battling large brush fire in Scarborough
articles.author: Daniel Kool
articles.summary: Fire crews are battling a brush fire in the marsh along Highland Avenue, Scarborough, near where it intersects with Lilac Lane. A forest service helicopter is dropping water on the blaze. Residents are urged to avoid the area. Maine has seen several brush fires in recent weeks, and most of the state is under a high risk of wildfire.

articles.title: On Mental Health: Earth Day reflections – climate change and our mental health
articles.author: Sarah Tesla
articles.summary: It was Earth Day this week. Mental health professional explains the link between climate change and mental health. Research shows that climate-related stress contributes to rising rates of anxiety, depression and post-traumatic stress disorder. Some people are more vulnerable to the effects of climate change than others. Community can offer emotional comfort and practical help during times of crisis.

articles.title: Climate change worsening malaria
articles.author: Our Correspondent
articles.summary: Climate change is worsening the impact of malaria in Pakistan. World Malaria Day is observed on 25 April. Pakistan screened over 11.4 million malaria suspects and provided treatment to 2 million confirmed malaria patients in 2014. 7.8 million insecticide treated nets were distributed across 22 high-malaria burden districts of the country.

articles.title: Wrong, New York Times, Climate Change Isn't Disrupting Blood Supplies
articles.author: Anthony Watts
articles.summary: NYT claims that global warming is threatening the world's blood supply due to extreme weather events. There is no scientific evidence that climate change is causing a new global blood crisis. The article mentions Hurricane Helene and California wildfires causing canceled blood drives. It also mentions a rise in blood-transmissible diseases like West Nile and dengue.

articles.title: England declares war on sunlight
articles.author: Editorial Board
articles.summary: British government's Advanced Research and Invention Agency will soon be spraying material in the skies above the perpetually overcast island to amplify the gloom and lower the average temperature. Nobody at 10 Downing St. recoiled at the nonsensical urgency underlying the stratagem to 'buy time to decarbonize' by interfering with the sun.

articles.title: Cambodia hosts ASEAN climate outlook forum, with focus on heatwaves, public health
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: The 24th ASEAN Climate Outlook Forum was held in Phnom Penh, capital of Cambodia, on Thursday. The forum was attended by climate experts from Asean member states and representatives from the World Meteorological Organization, ASEan Specialized Meteorological Center, and Regional Integrated Multi-Hazard Early Warning System. Cambodian Minister of Water Resources and Meteorology Thor Chetha said A SEAN has emerged as a hotspot for the impacts brought on by the changing climate.

articles.title: HEADLINE: 'Climate Change Myths Part 1: Polar Bears, Arctic Ice, and Food Shortages', Charles Rotter, John Stossel
articles.author: Charles Rotter
articles.summary: The era of global warming is over. The Arctic will be ice-free by the summer of 2030. Polar bears are close to extinction. The sea ice in the Arctic has been stable for the past 20 years. Environmental groups ignore the fact that polar bears have increased their populations.

articles.title: NC climate center reopens following funding lapse from Trump administration
articles.author: Kyle Ingram
articles.summary: The Southeast Regional Climate Center in North Carolina has resumed operations after the Trump administration reversed a halt in funding. The center provides crucial data to meteorologists, scientist and farmers in the region. It is housed at UNC-Chapel Hill and provides data to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which has been targeted for job cuts.

articles.title: Tampa council unites to slow coastal development as hurricane season looms
articles.summary: Tampa's Coastal High Hazard Areas (CHHA) are vulnerable to hurricane damage. Tampa City Council wants to crack down on development in the CHHA. Council member Bill Carlson says it's not about developers versus NIMBYs, but about protecting lives. Councilmember Alan Clendenin warns against overdevelopment.

articles.title: DOGE lists $1.7 billion in savings found over past two weeks
articles.author: Thérèse Boudreaux
articles.summary: There will be scattered thunderstorms early, then cloudy skies after midnight. It will be 60 degrees with 60% chance of rain at some point in the day. The weather will be light and variable.    For more information, go to: http://www.gofundme.com/cnnstorm

articles.title: Worst Coral Mass Bleaching on Record Caused By Warming Oceans
articles.author: Scientific American
articles.summary: The world is experiencing the most intense global coral bleaching event on record. 84 percent of reefs are experiencing heat stress from warming oceans, according to the UN.   -       in this case, the coral reefs are suffering from heat stress.

articles.title: A Grim Signal: Atmospheric CO2 Soared in 2024
articles.author: Bob Berwyn
articles.summary: There was a record annual jump in the global mean concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere measured in 2024. It's about 40 percent more than the pre-industrial level and enough to heat the planet by about 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit (1.5 degrees Celsius). Climate researchers have noted that the continuing increase of global CO2 emissions means the world will probably not be able to reach the Paris Agreement target.

articles.title: Why is the field on fire? Controlled burn in North Dumfries spurs regrowth in wilderness area
articles.author: Record staff
articles.summary: A five-hectare grassland at F.W.R. Dickson Wilderness Area burns on Thursday, April 24. The controlled burn was an effort by the Grand River Conservation Authority to destroy non-native plants and encourage the regrowth of deep-rooted native prairie grasses.

articles.title: Why is the field on fire? Controlled burn in North Dumfries spurs regrowth in wilderness area
articles.author: Mathew McCarthy/
articles.summary: A five-hectare grassland at F.W.R. Dickson Wilderness Area burns on Thursday, April 24. The controlled burn was an effort by the Grand River Conservation Authority to destroy non-native plants and encourage the regrowth of deep-rooted native prairie grasses. The area has been burned in this way nine times since 1995.

articles.title: Millions of birds are flying through Oregon, and they could use a little help
articles.author: Joel Odom
articles.summary: Millions of birds are migrating north through Oregon over the next few weeks. Wednesday is a Lights Out 'red alert' night, with 3.6 million birds expected to be flying through the Oregon skies. Bird Alliance of Oregon's Lights Out program encourages Oregonians to turn off outdoor lights and close their curtains or blinds to aid birds during their migration.

articles.title: Analysis shows that tree diversity builds climate resilience and boosts economic return
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: In the face of mounting threats from climate change, mixed species are being left alone to adapt to the changing climate and climate change effects on species. In the end, it's a win-win situation for all of us.   Â

articles.title: Sen. Angus King hits intelligence report for deleting climate change threat
articles.author: People's World
articles.summary: The 2025 Annual Threat Assessment of the U.S. Intelligence Community made no mention of climate change as a security threat for the first time in 11 years, according to Sen. Angus King. Much of the Senate Intelligence Committee hearing last was "sloppy, careless, incompetent behavior"

articles.title: How Kolkata's Drivers Are Coping With Extreme Heat
articles.summary: Bengal is feeling the effects of climate change and global warming. Heat waves and cyclones are more common and air pollution is increasing. Kolkata will experience 188 days of dangerous heat every year from 2019 to 2024. The coming months will be tough for city-dwellers, especially for those whose livelihoods or living situations compel them to spend most of their time outdoors. One such group is drivers, including private chauffeurs, app-cab drivers, bus drivers, auto drivers, and delivery agents.

articles.title: Climate Change Awareness & Action seeking to reverse environmental damage in CNY
articles.author: Laura Koch
articles.summary: Peter Wirth is the vice president of the organization Climate Change Awareness and Action. The organization started as an informal group of volunteers ten years ago. It has grown to become a 350.org group with monthly meetings and a board of directors. Peter had solar panels installed on his roof 13 years ago and he will get 15 years of free electricity from them. The group will be tabling at the 'The Effects of Gravity' show at the Center for the Arts of Homer this weekend.

articles.title: Study Estimates Fossil Fuel Giants Have Inflicted $28 Trillion in Climate Damage Worldwide
articles.author: Julia Conley
articles.summary: Dartmouth College researchers estimated that 111 of the world's largest fossil fuel companies have caused $28 trillion in heat-related climate damages so far. Half of that amount could be attributed to 10 oil, coal, and gas companies including Chevron, ExxonMobil, BP, Shell, Russia's state-owned Gazprom, and Saudi Aramco.

articles.title: Frozen alarm
articles.author: Editor'S Mail
articles.summary: The recent hailstorm in Islamabad is a stark reminder of how climate change is intensifying extreme weather events in Pakistan. Pakistan has seen a rise in unpredictable weather, from devastating floods to prolonged heatwaves, and now, intense hailstours. The Islamabad hailstorn underscores the urgent need for better disaster preparedness and climate adaptation measures.

articles.title: Trump signs more executive orders reshaping American education
articles.author: Morgan Sweeney
articles.summary: There will be scattered thunderstorms early, then cloudy skies after midnight. It will be 60 degrees with 60% chance of rain at some point in the day. The weather will be light and variable.    For more information, go to: http://www.gofundme.com/cnnstorm

articles.title: World Penguin Day 2025: Know About Origin, Significance, Date And More About 'Flightless Sea Bird'
articles.author: Rahul M
articles.summary: World Penguin Day 2025 will be observed on April 25. It is dedicated to raising awareness about penguins, the flightless birds that live mostly in the Southern Hemisphere, especially in Antarctica. Penguins are an essential part of our ecosystem and face many challenges due to climate change and human activities.

articles.title: Climate Change and Environmental Policy
articles.summary: Climate change is about the Earth getting warmer because of human activity. We've already warmed the Earth by about 1.1°C since the 1800s, and we're on track for 2.4–3.5°C by 2100 if we don't step up our game. Even a small temperature bump can cause big problems. Sea levels are rising, glaciers are shrinking, storms are getting fiercer, and droughts are hitting harder. The people who contribute the least to climate change are often the ones suffering the most.

articles.title: Storm resiliency the topic of Coast Forward Summit & Open House
articles.author: Laura Walter
articles.summary: The Coast Forward Summit & Open House will be held on Thursday, May 1, hosted by the Delaware Center for the Inland Bays. The event is in support of the CIB's two-year Southern Delaware Coastal Resilience Plan. The CIB is wrapping up the public survey with additional input at the event.

articles.title: Saving Sinking Homes
articles.author: Jess Zhang
articles.summary: Climate change is escalating a housing crisis in Alaska's Native villages. Alaska is warming two to three times faster than the global average. In Nunapitchuk, water damage during the 2020 floods rendered several homes uninhabitable, forcing some displaced residents to move in with friends and family.

articles.title: Explained: What Is A Heatwave And How To Stay Safe
articles.author: OT Staff
articles.summary: IMD has issued a heatwave warning for Northern and Central India. Yellow alerts have been issued at Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan, and Haryana. Gujarat, Tamil Nadu, Madhyam Pradesh, and Maharashtra are likely to experience hot and humid conditions till April 25.

articles.title: World's coral reefs under largest bleaching event: U.S. science agency
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: The world's coral reefs are experiencing the fourth and largest global bleaching event in recorded history, according to NOAA data. It affected 83.7 percent of the world's reef area between January 2023 and April 2025, with affected reefs spanning at least 83 countries and territories. The previous record was set during the third bleaching period, which lasted from 2014 to 2017.

articles.title: UK Plots to Blot Out the Sun
articles.author: from
articles.summary: Aria, the Government's advanced research and invention funding agency, has set aside £50 million for projects, which will be announced in the coming weeks. Experts believe that pollution over shipping routes made clouds brighter and therefore more reflective, resulting in dimmer sunlight. They also say that international regulations to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions caused an increase in global warming.

articles.title: Government will pay to 'dim the Sun' in bid to tackle global warming
articles.author: Howard Lloyd
articles.summary: The UK Government is set to unveil funding of up to £50m for experiments aimed at reducing the amount of sunlight that reaches the Earth's surface. This technology seeks to reflect a portion of the sun's rays back into space to slow down rising temperatures. Last year was the hottest on record, with 2024 going down in history as the first year the average temperatures soared past the 1.5C mark above pre-industrial levels.

articles.title: Plans to 'dim the sun' sparks conspiracy the government is 'changing the weather
articles.author: Katie Boyden
articles.summary: The Advanced Research and Invention Agency (ARIA), sponsored by the government, has set aside £56.8m for projects aiming to create climate cooling, using measures such as injecting aerosols into the atmosphere or brightening clouds to reflect more sunshine. If the projects get the green light from the government in the space of weeks, Aria will start carrying out 'small controlled outdoor experiments on particular approaches'.

articles.title: Melting Arctic Ice Could Unleash Ancient Deadly Diseases, Scientists Warn
articles.summary: Permafrost thawing could release ancient bacteria or viruses that have been frozen for thousands of years. Scientists are already tracking rising cases of illnesses like brucellosis, tularemia, and E. coli in northern communities. The study pushes for urgent action, better disease surveillance, climate-resilient health systems and a 'One Health' approach.

articles.title: Greece to deploy record number of firefighters this year amid global warming, minister says, World News
articles.summary: Greece will deploy a record number of firefighters this year in anticipation of "bad scenarios" ahead. Last August, during Greece's hottest summer on record, a woman died and 10,000 hectares of land were burnt in a wildfire. Greece has earmarked some 2 billion euros to buy new aircraft, meteorological stations and drones to improve its capabilities against wildfires and other natural disasters.

articles.title: Scientists Say They Can Calculate the Cost of Oil Giants' Role In Global Warming
articles.author: Slashdot
articles.summary: Oil and gas companies are facing lawsuits over climate change. Two scientists have created a tool that calculates how much damage each company's pollution has caused and how much money they could be forced to pay if they're successfully sued. The analysis could fuel an emerging legal fight. Industry groups and companies tend to object to the methodologies of attribution science.

articles.title: Melting Arctic Ice Could Unleash Ancient Deadly Diseases, Scientists Warn
articles.author: Ashley Fike
articles.summary: As Arctic permafrost thaws, sea levels rise, so does the risk of dormant viruses, bacteria, and parasites re-entering the world after thousands of years. Scientists are already tracking rising cases of illnesses like brucellosis, tularemia, and E. coli in northern communities.

articles.title: Alaska's Fishing Industry Faces Uncertain Waters as NOAA Cuts Threaten Science, Safety, and Sustainability
articles.author: Alaska Native News
articles.summary: NOAA's climate research is experiencing significant cuts. The industry risks losing access to these essential tools. Climate-driven shifts in fish habitats may go unmonitored, leading to unexpected declines or overfishing for some species, or missed opportunity in others. NOAA's research helps predict changes in ocean conditions, enabling fisheries managers to adjust quotas and fishing seasons accordingly. The proposed budget cuts could lead to reorganization within federal agencies.

articles.title: Widespread drought threatens agriculture across Africa
articles.summary: There is a severe drought in northern, southern, and central-western Africa, along with northern Madagascar. The drought is due to prolonged low rainfall and elevated temperatures. It is threatening food security, agriculture, and water resources. The Zambezi basin and Madagascar are heavily impacted. Morocco and Algeria face particular challenges.

articles.title: Giant prehistoric kangaroos perished during 'climate upheaval'
articles.author: fin24
articles.summary: Giant prehistoric kangaroos perished when "climate upheaval" turned lush Australian rainforest into desert 300 000 years ago. The mega-herbivores weighed as much as 170 kilogrammes, almost twice as hefty as the chunkiest living kangaroo. The extinct "Protemnodon" bounded across Australia as many as five million years ago and the last population survived until around 40 000 ago.

articles.title: Global Warming is Mostly Caused By the Sun, Not Humans, Says Astrophysics Professor
articles.author: Hannes
articles.summary: There is no scientific consensus on the anthropogenic nature of climate change, according to astrophysicist Nir Shaviv. Up to two-thirds of the 20th century's warming is related to increased solar activity. The average temperature on the planet has risen by one degree Celsius since 1900, but this is not unprecedented.

articles.title: Giant icebergs the size of cities once drifted off the coast of Britain, scientists find
articles.author: The Independent
articles.summary: climate change and global warming are affecting Antarctica, research could indicate how current climate change, global warming affect Antarctica, as well as the current weather in the area.    in Antarctica.  in terms of the current temperature change and climate change in the region.

articles.title: Climate change is now the leading threat to imperiled species, new study finds
articles.author: Science X staff
articles.summary: In a study of 2,766 imperiled species across the United States and its territories, climate change now affects 91% of ESA-listed species within this group. The authors examined five dominant drivers of human-caused biodiversity loss: climate change, land and sea use change, species overexploitation, pollution, and invasive species.

articles.title: Climate Change Myths Part 1: Polar Bears, Arctic Ice, and Food Shortages
articles.author: Charles Rotter
articles.summary: The era of global warming has ended, according to John Stossel. The facts disprove the catastrophic claims of climate change fanatics. The next video and the next debunk 7 myths about climate change. They include melting ice, polar bear extinction, and climate change famines.

articles.title: Montana climate matters: An introduction
articles.author: CATHY WHITLOCK
articles.summary: Montana is 2-3F hotter now than in 1950, which equates to a rate of warming of about 0.2oF per decade. The Earth has warmed about 2oF since 1880, and an additional warming of 4-7oF is projected by the end of this century. The connection between increasing greenhouse gases and global warming has been understood by scientists for over 200 years.

articles.title: Drought Update: Severe drought status expanding in Eastern NC
articles.author: Jim Howard
articles.summary: After another dry run of days, drought conditions have expanded into western Jones, northern Craven, western Beaufort, eastern Martin, southern Craven and all of Washington County. Most of Eastern North Carolina remains in moderate drought status. The only improved conditions are the I-95 counties over the last few weeks. The scattered downpours we saw on April 23rd and more rain chances this Friday and Saturday should help improve the drought conditions. The next drought update is scheduled for May 1st.

articles.title: Greece to deploy record number of firefighters this year, minister says
articles.author: Ekathimerini
articles.summary: Greece will deploy a record number of firefighters this year in anticipation of 'bad scenarios' ahead, its climate crisis minister said on Thursday. There have been a succession of destructive wildfires in Greece recently. This year's climate conditions have been milder than in previous years.

articles.title: History's Biggest Liars?
articles.author: Issues
articles.summary: The global warming conspirators are world-class fabricators and truth suppressors, writes Peter Bergen. He claims that they are fabricating the truth.    "The truth is not what people think it is" and "what they say it is."

articles.title: Giant icebergs the size of cities once drifted off the coast of Britain, scientists find
articles.author: Jabed Ahmed
articles.summary: Giant icebergs the size of Norwich were drifting off the coast of Britain during the last ice age. They dragged across the North Sea seabed between 18,000 and 20,000 years ago and left behind a sequence of characteristic, comb-like grooves preserved in sediment close to Aberdeen, Scotland. An ice sheet covering much of the British and Irish Isles was retreating due to a warming climate. The research could indicate how current climate change and global warming are impacting Antarctica.

articles.title: Webinar focuses on coastal flooding
articles.author: Daily Republic Staff
articles.summary: The Coastal Conservancy is hosting a webinar featuring state and federal officials to discuss coastal flood risk and related shoreline resilience. The webinar is set for 10 to 11:30 a.m. on May 12 in Fairfield, California.    .

articles.title: Global coral bleaching event impacts 83.7% of reefs, setting record levels of heat stress
articles.author: Famagusta Gazette
articles.summary: The world's coral reefs are undergoing the largest global bleaching event in recorded history, according to NOAA data. Between January 2023 and April 2025, bleaching-level heat stress has affected 83.7% of the world's corals, says Famedusta Gazette.

articles.title: In Britain, we burn precious peatland for sport
articles.author: Tim Smedley
articles.summary: There is a new consultation on grouse moor management by the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs, which closes on 25th May. Peat bogs are England's largest carbon store, covering about 11% of the country and holding an estimated 584m tonnes of carbon. It takes around 10 years for each centimetre of peat to form, meaning such depths amount to 400 years' worth of carbon capture and storage.

articles.title: BBC Learning English - 6 Minute English / How climate change affects animal migration
articles.author: BBC Learning English
articles.summary: Neil and Beth discuss animal migration and teach you some new vocabulary for 6 Minute English. They talk about the annual migration of wildebeest around the Serengeti in Tanzania and the Maasai Mara in Kenya. Trisha Atwood is the host of BBC World Service's The Climate Question. She explains that sharks can help fight climate change.

articles.title: The real reason heatwaves happen
articles.author: Oghenerume Progress
articles.summary: Nigeria is experiencing a heatwave with temperatures soaring up to 42°C in some areas. Global warming and climate change are making heatwaves more frequent and intense. The Harmattan season is over, so the sun is stronger and without the protective winds, the temperatures rise rapidly.

articles.title: Australian study reveals why massive kangaroos went extinct
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Ancient giant kangaroos from central Queensland of Australia were stay-at-home creatures. Their home ranges were no larger than those of modern kangaroo species. Their limited mobility left them unable to adapt or relocate, leading to their extinction. Scientists used cutting-edge isotopic analysis to uncover details of the species.

articles.title: Climate adaptation in agriculture: Time to address an often ignored gender perspective
articles.author: Rt Rev Dr Emily Onyango
articles.summary: God created both men and women to have dominion over and care for creation. In traditional societies, women play a crucial role in agriculture. Historically, the world was patriarchal and women had little say in decision-making processes. In the pre-colonial era, women owned property and land. Women were the primary owners of the home, which included agricultural products. After Christianity, men became heads of households and women were relegated to roles within the kitchen.

articles.title: NZ scientists raise alarm over U.S. shutdown of key scientific databases
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: New Zealand scientists are concerned about the planned decommissioning of several public scientific databases by the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. NOAA announced changes earlier this month that will affect data sources related to earthquakes, marine, coastal, and estuarine sciences. The move comes amid growing concerns about the erosion of public access to scientific data in the US.

articles.title: Climate Change Tops Threats to Endangered Species: Study
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: In a study of 2766 imperiled species across the United States and its territories, 91% of them are ESA-listed species. Climate change is the most pervasive threat to these species. It's the first time that this driver has been identified to surpass other causes of biodiversity loss for this group.

articles.title: Greece's Record-Breaking Firefighting Force Gears Up for Wildfire Season
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Greece is making unprecedented preparations for the upcoming wildfire season. The government will mobilize 18,000 firefighters, supported by thousands of volunteers, to tackle similar threats during the official wildfire season starting May 1. Greece is also investing around 2 billion euros to enhance its firefighting capabilities with new aircraft, meteorological stations, and drones equipped with thermal cameras.

articles.title: Full spring season of programming at the Pembroke 50+ Active Living Centre
articles.author: Arlene Ling
articles.summary: Canada Geese have returned, but some of them are worried about the timing of their arrival due to recent snowfall and recent frosty mornings. Still, some spring-like plants are starting to grow in the soil, and a light green is emerging, a sign of warmer, brighter days ahead.

articles.title: Climate Change: Where are We and Where are We Going, in Five Recent Books?
articles.author: KLG
articles.summary: There is no escape from the effects of climate change. The Uninhabitable Earth: Life After Warming by David Wallace-Wells is about what warming means to the way we live on the planet. It is not about the science of anthropogenic global warming (AGW). It is about how humans will adapt to a warming world.

articles.title: Global coral bleaching event impacts 83.7% of reefs, setting record levels of heat stress
articles.summary: The world's coral reefs are undergoing the largest global bleaching event in recorded history. It has affected 83.7% of coral reef areas across at least 83 countries and territories. The previous record was 68.2% of reefs. Rising ocean temperatures force corals to expel algae living within their tissues.

articles.title: China's Pollution Cuts May Have Accelerated Global Warming
articles.author: Monitor News Bureau
articles.summary: China's efforts to curb sulphur pollution from coal plants, vehicles and industries over the past two decades may have inadvertently sped up global warming. Global temperatures rose by around 0.07°C due to reduced sulphur emissions, particularly since 2010. Sulphur dioxide converts into sulphate aerosols in the atmosphere, which cool the planet by reflecting sunlight and enhancing cloud formation.

articles.title: NOAA reports 84% of global coral reefs face unprecedented bleaching crisis
articles.author: JERUSALEM POST STAFF
articles.summary: A coral bleaching crisis is gripping the planet, with approximately 84 percent of the world's coral reefs now bleached and in danger. The current bleaching event has exceeded the previous episode from 2014 to 2017, which affected approximately two-thirds of the reefs, and is now the most severe of its kind in history. Last year was the hottest on Earth, with heating of the oceans contributing to the ongoing coral bleach crisis. Coral reefs are home to a quarter of all marine species and support high levels of biodiversity, providing food and protection to one billion people.

articles.title: Family in Indonesia turns to mangrove trees to tackle climate change
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Pasijah, 55, lives in Rejosari Senik, a small village on Java's northern coast that was once on dry land but is now submerged in water. Neighbours have abandoned their homes, vegetable plots and rice fields to the advancing sea, but Pasijah and her family have no plans to leave.

articles.title: Photos: Indonesian family turns to mangrove trees to tackle climate change
articles.summary: Pasijah, 55, lives in Rejosari Senik, a small village on Java's northern coast that was once on dry land but is now submerged in water. Her neighbours have abandoned their homes, vegetable plots and rice fields to the advancing sea, but she and her family have no plans to leave. She has planted about 15,000 mangrove trees a year over the past 20 years to protect her house.

articles.title: Major Study Shows The Silent Majority Are Over It: 89% Want Climate Action, But Think They're Alone
articles.summary: A survey of 130,000 people in 125 countries found that 89% want their governments to do more to combat global warming. The 89 Percent Project was launched this past week in sync with Earth Day. It's a global team-up with media outlets like Covering Climate Now (CCNow) and Agence France-Presse.

articles.title: Agriculture and Climate Change: What Does the Future Hold?
articles.author: Compiled Staff
articles.summary: Drought in the Netherlands has become increasingly common. Extreme weather events are having a major effect on farmers. Emma Knol is developing a tool that highlights the impact of climate change on farmers at the business level and identifies measures to ensure the future viability of agriculture. The number of suitable locations for the current cultivation of crops will continuously shrink and sometimes crop cultivation will be relocated.

articles.title: Countries could use forests to 'mask' needed emission cuts: report
articles.author: Kelly MACNAMARA AFP
articles.summary: Major economies are overstating how much carbon their forests can absorb in a climate accounting fudge, according to new research. Brazil and Australia are singled out in the assessment. Scientists are still unsure about how carbon sinks might behave as the planet warms in future.

articles.title: Countries could use forests to 'mask' needed emission cuts: report
articles.author: Kelly MACNAMARA
articles.summary: Major economies are overstating how much carbon their forests can absorb in a climate accounting fudge, according to new research. The assessment singled out Brazil and Australia. It warned a lack of rules around accounting for forests and other land-based carbon sinks meant countries could "game the system" when reporting their national greenhouse gas emissions.

articles.title: Schools are facing this creeping threat as temperatures rise
articles.author: Kate Allen
articles.summary: As spring temperatures rise, so too does the threat to kids. Without urgent action, children's safety and ability to learn are at risk. Climate change creates a springboard for longer, hotter and earlier heatwaves, according to an ' urgent call ' backed by more than 40 organizations.

articles.title: Creating the best possible climate models is existential
articles.author: Alexander Pui
articles.summary: Tokyo saw its warmest summer and fall last year, smashing the previous record of 2023. It was the hottest year on record in Japan, in keeping with a global trend. A persistent run of global heat that started in May 2023 has rattled some in the climate science community. Evidence of the factors behind accelerated warming is mixed.

articles.title: Scientists: Giant Kangaroos Perished During 'Climate Upheaval'
articles.author: Asharq Al Awsat
articles.summary: Giant prehistoric kangaroos perished when "climate upheaval" turned lush Australian rainforest into desert 300,000 years ago.
